pair.Prompt: In Hopkins v. United States, the Court held that an agreement among members of an exchange not to transact business with non-members does not constitute interstate commerce.
pair.Response: Response: On October Term, 1898, the Court held that the business of the defendants in Hopkins v. United States was primarily and substantially the buying and selling of live stock as commission merchants at the stock yards in Kansas City. The Court further held that the agreement among members of the exchange not to transact business with non-members did not constitute interstate commerce, as it was simply a means by and through which the individual members who had become associated were the better enabled to transact their business. The Court concluded that the agreement was not a contract in restraint of interstate trade or commerce.
